hints_html: How can the row reduced version of A help you find the column space?
hints_latex:
How can the row reduced version of \emph{A} help you find the column
space?
hints_raw: How can the row reduced version of ''A'' help you find the column space?
question: 8 (a)
sols_html:
The basis of the column space of A are the columns of A corresponding to the linearly independent columns of the row-reduced version of A. We will find the row reduced matrix for A by performing Gaussian elimination as follows:

\(\left[\begin{array}{ccccc} 1 & 0 & -1 & 2 & 4 \\ 0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\ -1 & -2 & 5 & 1 & 4 \\ 1 & 0 & -1 & 1 & 2 \end{array}\right]\)

Add row 1 to row 3; subtract row 1 from row 4.

\(\left[\begin{array}{ccccc} 1 & 0 & -1 & 2 & 4 \\ 0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & -2 & 4 & 3 & 8 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -2 \end{array}\right]\).

Add twice row 2 to row 3.

\(\left[\begin{array}{ccccc} 1 & 0 & -1 & 2 & 4 \\ 0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 3 & 6 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -2 \end{array}\right]\).

Multiply row 3 by 1/3.

\(\left[\begin{array}{ccccc} 1 & 0 & -1 & 2 & 4 \\ 0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -2 \end{array}\right]\).

Subtract twice row 3 from row 1; add row 3 to row 4

\(\left[\begin{array}{ccccc} 1 & 0 & -1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array}\right]\).

The row reduced version of A has columns 1, 2, and 4 as linearly independent vectors. Therefore, the basis of the column space will be the first, second and fourth column of the original matrix A. Hence a basis for the column space is:

\(\left\{ \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \\ -1 \\ 1 \end{array} \right], \left[\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] , \left[\begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] \right\}\).
sols_latex:
The basis of the column space of \emph{A} are the columns of \emph{A}
corresponding to the linearly independent columns of the row-reduced
version of \emph{A}. We will find the row reduced matrix for \emph{A} by
performing Gaussian elimination as follows:

$\left[\begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 0 & -1 & 2 & 4 \\
0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\
-1 & -2 & 5 & 1 & 4 \\
1 & 0 & -1 & 1 & 2
\end{array}\right]$

Add row 1 to row 3; subtract row 1 from row 4.

$\left[\begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 0 & -1 & 2 & 4 \\
0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\
0 & -2 & 4 & 3 & 8 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -2
\end{array}\right]$.

Add twice row 2 to row 3.

$\left[\begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 0 & -1 & 2 & 4 \\
0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 3 & 6 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -2
\end{array}\right]$.

Multiply row 3 by 1/3.

$\left[\begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 0 & -1 & 2 & 4 \\
0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 2 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -2
\end{array}\right]$.

Subtract twice row 3 from row 1; add row 3 to row 4

$\left[\begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 0 & -1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 2 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right]$.

The row reduced version of A has columns 1, 2, and 4 as linearly
independent vectors. Therefore, the basis of the column space will be
the first, second and fourth column of the \textbf{original} matrix
\emph{A}. Hence a basis for the column space is:

$\left\{ \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \\ -1 \\ 1 \end{array} \right], \left[\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] , \left[\begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] \right\}$.
sols_raw:
The basis of the column space of ''A'' are the columns of ''A'' corresponding to the linearly independent columns of the row-reduced version of ''A''.  We will find the row reduced matrix for ''A'' by performing Gaussian elimination as follows:

<math>\left[\begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 0 & -1 & 2 & 4 \\
0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\
-1 & -2 & 5 & 1 & 4 \\
1 & 0 & -1 & 1 & 2
\end{array}\right]</math>

Add row 1 to row 3; subtract row 1 from row 4.

<math>\left[\begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 0 & -1 & 2 & 4 \\
0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\
0 & -2 & 4 & 3 & 8 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -2
\end{array}\right]</math>.

Add twice row 2 to row 3.

<math>\left[\begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 0 & -1 & 2 & 4 \\
0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 3 & 6 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -2
\end{array}\right]</math>.

Multiply row 3 by 1/3.

<math>\left[\begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 0 & -1 & 2 & 4 \\
0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 2 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -2
\end{array}\right]</math>.

Subtract twice row 3 from row 1; add row 3 to row 4

<math>\left[\begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 0 & -1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 2 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right]</math>.

The row reduced version of A has columns 1, 2, and 4 as linearly independent vectors.  Therefore, the basis of the column space will be the first, second and fourth column of the '''original''' matrix ''A''.  Hence a basis for the column space is:  

<math>\left\{ \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \\ -1 \\ 1 \end{array} \right], \left[\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] , \left[\begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] \right\} </math>.
statement_html:
Consider the matrix

\[\begin{aligned} A = \left(\begin{array}{ccccc} 1 & 0 & -1 & 2 & 4 \\ 0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\ -1 & -2 & 5 & 1 & 4 \\ 1 & 0 & -1 & 1 & 2 \end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\]

a) Find a basis for the column space of A.
statement_raw:
Consider the matrix

:<math>
A = \left(\begin{array}{ccccc}
1 & 0 & -1 & 2 & 4 \\
0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & -1 \\
-1 & -2 & 5 & 1 & 4 \\
1 & 0 & -1 & 1 & 2
\end{array}\right)
</math>

'''a)''' Find a basis for the column space of ''A''.
